Attack Scenario Summary: Attacker injects XSS to steal tokens from localStorage and impersonate victim
Attacker uses leaked credentials from other breaches to access accounts
Attacker phishes admin credentials via fake login page
Attacker tricks victim into using attacker-controlled session token
Stolen refresh token used indefinitely to obtain new access tokens
Attacker sends phishing emails appearing to come from platform
Attacker injects SQL to bypass tenant filters and access all data
Attacker adds unauthorized fields to requests to escalate privileges
Attacker uploads malware disguised as PDF; users infected on download
Attacker modifies queue messages to execute wrong jobs or send to wrong recipients
Attacker injects HTML/JS into contact name; rendered in PDF without escaping

Threat Title: Data Tampering via Broken Access Control
Attack Scenario Summary: Attacker modifies resources without authorization check (IDOR)

Threat Title: Missing Audit Logs for Admin Actions
Attack Scenario Summary: Admin actions not logged; cannot investigate or prove malicious activity
No proof of tenant authorization for subscription charges

Threat Title: Log Tampering or Deletion by Attacker
Attack Scenario Summary: Attacker deletes logs to hide evidence of breach
User exfiltrates data but no logs exist to prove it
User from Tenant A accesses Tenant B resources by guessing IDs

Threat Title: Excessive Data Exposure in API Responses
Attack Scenario Summary: API returns unnecessary fields like password_hash or internal IDs
S3 bucket accidentally public; all files exposed
Logs contain passwords or tokens; accessible to unauthorized parties
Verbose error messages reveal database schema and stack traces
User downloads files belonging to other users/tenants by guessing IDs
Response time differences reveal valid email addresses

Threat Title: Cache Poisoning Leading to Data Leak
Attack Scenario Summary: Attacker poisons cache with cross-tenant data via key collision

Threat Title: Verbose API Responses Exposing Business Logic
Attack Scenario Summary: API exposes internal state revealing approval thresholds and rules
Database backups not encrypted; attacker gains access and restores DB
Attacker sends complex queries without pagination exhausting database
Attacker uploads thousands of max-size files exhausting storage quota
Attacker enqueues millions of messages overwhelming workers
Vulnerable regex causes catastrophic backtracking exhausting threads
Attacker uses botnet to send millions of requests per second
User grants themselves admin role via unprotected endpoint

Threat Title: SSRF via Import from URL Feature
Attack Scenario Summary: Attacker fetches AWS metadata endpoint stealing credentials
Admin impersonates users without MFA or audit trail
